title: Superhero Treatment for Sound Sensitivity
chief_complaint: I have extreme distress, anger, and frustration when I hear specific trigger sounds like chewing, breathing, and hiccups. It affects my concentration, sleep, and ability to eat dinner with my family.

problem_summary.onset: Months prior to the initial visit in July 2017.
problem_summary.associated_symptoms: Physical reflexes (inhaling, tensing shoulders, squeezing hands), anxiety, depression, visual triggers (seeing someone eat).
problem_summary.functional_impact: Disrupted family dynamics, inability to eat at the dinner table without noise-cancelling protection, social/recreational withdrawal.
problem_summary.goals_motivation: Currently using noise-cancelling headphones but seeking help due to severity.

history.present_illness: Patient reports sound sensitivity to chewing, breathing, and hiccups. Exposure triggers extreme emotional distress (rage, disgust). She currently wears noise-cancelling hearing protection at the dinner table, a strategy suggested by her psychologist.
history.otologic_history: No history of ear disease, drainage, sudden hearing loss, dizziness, or ear pain.
history.medical_psych_history: Diagnosed with anxiety and depression linked to the effects of triggering sounds.
history.prior_management: Use of noise-cancelling headphones; working with a clinical psychologist.

tests.name: Otoscopy
tests.key_findings: Clear ear canals with intact tympanic membranes.

tests.name: Pure-tone audiometry
tests.key_findings: Hearing sensitivity is within normal limits bilaterally. Thresholds are generally 0-10 dB HL across frequencies 250-8000 Hz.

tests.name: Sound Tolerance (UCL)
tests.key_findings: Uncomfortable loudness levels (UCL) indicate mild-to-moderate hyperacusis.

tests.name: Questionnaires
tests.key_findings: Scores indicate severe misophonia. Patient reports visual triggers and severe emotional distress (hate, anger, rage).

overall_audiologic_summary: The patient presents with normal hearing sensitivity bilaterally but reduced sound tolerance (UCLs 70-90 dB HL) consistent with mild-to-moderate hyperacusis. Questionnaire results (A-MISO-S: 17, MAQ: 48) confirm severe misophonia with associated visual triggers and intense emotional reactions.
counseling_points: Overuse of hearing protection can actually heighten your sensitivity to sound; we recommend reducing its use.
Instead of blocking sound, we recommend using earphones to play pink noise (a neutral sound) to provide gentle stimulation to the auditory system.
Enrich the sound environment at the dinner table with music or nature sounds to reduce the contrast of trigger sounds.
Your reaction is a conditioned reflex involving connections between the hearing and emotional centers of the brain; therapy aims to weaken these connections.
notes_for_actor: Portray a teenager who is articulate but clearly distressed and frustrated by specific sounds.
When describing triggers (chewing, breathing), express intense emotions like anger or rage, not just annoyance.
Demonstrate the physical reflex described: inhaling sharply, tensing shoulders, and squeezing hands when imagining or discussing triggers.
Emphasize that you feel like you might lose control or hurt someone, even though you never actually act on it.
